newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SAfrica, Swaziland agree customs union sugar levels.
newsitem.headline: SAfrica, Swaziland agree customs union sugar levels.

text.p: The South African and Swaziland sugar industries have agreed that sales of Swazi sugar into the South African Customs Union will remain at last season's levels, the two said in a joint statement released on Monday.

"These arrangements are for the current 1997/98 season and it is the intention of both parties that the proposed arrangement is entirely without prejudice to the position of either party in the forthcoming discussions around the proposed SADC (Southern African Development Community) Sugar Protocol," the association said in a statement.
The association did not give any figures.
The statement follows a recent stand-off between the two industries after South Africa accused Swaziland of dumping cheaper sugar into its domestic market.
Swaziland benefits from preferential quotas into the European Union and the United States.

"This agreement creates the opportunity for the industries to negotiate the reinstatement by SASA (South African Sugar Association) of their training, research and port facilities," the statement said.
Production forecasts were exchanged during the talks in Swaziland late last month and it was agreed that production in excess of these tonnages would be exported out of the region.

The Swazi government and the South African department of trade and industry were satisfied, and arrangements were being made for a meeting in Durban on July 16 and 17 to discuss the SADC sugar protocol, the statement said.
South Africa, Swaziland, Lesotho, Botswana and Namibia make up the customs union states.
SADC members include Mauritius, Angola, Lesotho, Swaziland, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Mozambique, Tanzania, Malawi, South Africa and Botswana.
